bestBHT.bht: The chief captain was afraid after realizing that he had bound a Roman citizen, fearing the consequences of his actions. The soldiers were about to torture Paul by scourging him, but upon hearing that he was a Roman, they immediately stopped and backed off. It is notable that the old magical power of the words Civis Romanus sum still held weight, as Paul's status as a Roman citizen had a significant impact, prompting fear and causing the soldiers to cease their actions.

Henry Alford: The centurion believed Paul’s word, because a false claim of this nature, being easily exposed, and punishable with death, was almost an unprecedented thing." (Hackett)
His fear was on account of his first false step; but it was now too late to reverse it." (Commentary)
The same reason which leads him to continue it now, operates afterwards when the hearing was delayed." (Commentary)
Albert Barnes: They saw that by scourging him they would have Violated the Roman law, and exposed themselves to its penalty.
Who were about to torture him by scourging him.
It is a heinous sin to bind a Roman citizen; it is wickedness to beat him; it is next to parricide to kill him, and what Shall I say to crucify him?
Philip Schaff: It is noticeable how the word rendered ‘should have examined’ had acquired the sense of ‘examining by torture.’
The old magical power of the words, Civis Romanus sum, ‘ I am a Roman citizen,’ was by no means gone when Paul spoke to the soldiers of the tower of Antonia.

There is no doubt but that the statement of Acts 22:29, which states how ‘the chief captain was afraid’ because he had bound a Roman, refers not to the fact simply of his being fettered, but to his having been fastened to the pillar to receive the blows of the rods.
Archibald T. Robertson: Departed from him...stood off from him at once."
Was afraid...became afraid. He had reason to be."
That he was a Roman...indirect assertion with tense of εστιν retained.
John Gill: By scourging; namely, the soldiers, who under the inspection of the centurion, and by the order of the chief captain, were binding him with thongs to scourge him, and thereby extort from him his crime...
...but hearing that he was a Roman, either of their own accord, or rather at the order of their officers, either the centurion or chief captain, or both, left binding him, and went their way...

And the chief captain also was afraid after he knew that he was a Roman; lest he should be called to an account for his conduct, and his commission should be taken from him: chiefly, and because he had bound him...
